PROCEDURE

The case originated in an application (no. 12768/02) against the Republic of Austria lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by an Austrian national, Mr Bernhard Mok (“the applicant”), on 29 May 2001.

The applicant was represented by Mr L. Weiß, a lawyer practising in Gföhl. The Austrian Government (“the Government”) were represented by their Agent, Mr F. Trauttmansdorff, Head of the International Law Department at the Federal Ministry of European and International Affairs.

On 17 November 2006 the Court declared the application partly inadmissible and decided to communicate the complaints concerning the length of the proceedings, the lack of remedies in that respect and the alleged breach of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention to the Government. Under the provisions of Article 29 § 3 of the Convention, it decided to examine the merits of the application at the same time as its admissibility.

THE FACTS

I. THE CIRCUMSTANCES OF THE CASE

The applicant was born in 1945 and lives in Gföhl.

1. The administrative proceedings

The applicant owned a forest and a sawmill.

On 2 June 1986, upon a request lodged by the authorities, he was ordered to carry out roadworks.

On 24 March 1998 the Vorarlberg Regional Government (Landesregierung) ordered the applicant to carry out certain road and bridge works because, due to his failure to abide by the previous order, he was in breach of forest regulations.

On 17 September 1998 the applicant submitted to the Regional Government that no building permit or decision on a specific forest use existed for the planned road and bridge. Furthermore, he alleged that the Regional Government had failed to indicate the forest area to be cut or the amount of wood to be processed in the sawmill.

On 10 November 1998 the applicant withdrew his building request. On the same date the Regional Government imposed a fine of 2,500 Austrian Schillings (ATS) on him.

On 21 January 1999 the applicant lodged an objection against the decision.

On 28 June 1999 the Federal Minister for Agriculture and Forestry dismissed the applicant's objection.

The Administrative Court rejected the applicant's request for judicial review on 11 January 2000.

2. The judicial proceedings

On 24 February 1999 the applicant lodged a complaint with the Constitutional Court. He complained, inter alia, about the non-existence of a system of constitutional review of administrative acts.

On 28 June 1999 the Constitutional Court declined to deal with his complaint since the decision under dispute was not a special enactment. However, the Constitutional Court remitted the case to the Administrative Court, finding that the Administrative Court had failed to examine the complaint that the Road Traffic Act did not meet the requirements of the Constitution as regards road building in forests (see paragraphs 22 to 24 below).

On 11 July 2000 the Administrative Court dismissed the complaint. It found, inter alia, that despite the applicant's allegation, the enactment did not allow the arbitrary imposition of forestry works by the authorities since it was only applicable to persons whose business included forestry.

In the meantime, the Constitutional Court on 25 July 2000 had declined to deal with the applicant's complaint lodged on 26 June 1999. It found that the enactment complied with the provisions of the Federal Forest Act (Bundesforstgesetz 1969) and the Federal Forestry Ordinance (Bundesforstverordnung).

The decision was served on the applicant on 14 August 2000.

PROCEDURE

The case originated in an application (no. 9357/06) against the Republic of Turkey lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Turkish national, Mr Ahmet Hüseyinoğlu (“the applicant”), on 7 February 2006.

The applicant was represented by Mr Mehmet Hüseyinoğlu, a lawyer practising in Istanbul. The Turkish Government (“the Government”) were represented by their Agent.

On 30 June 2009 the President of the Second Section decided to give notice of the application to the Government. It was also decided to examine the merits of the application at the same time as its admissibility (Article 29 § 3).

SUMMARY OF THE FACTS

The applicant was born in 1942 and lives in Istanbul.

A. Background to the case

The applicant started working with the Ministry of Finance in 1961. In 1996 he was appointed as the General Manager of the Istanbul Stock Exchange and he continued to hold this position until 2002.

On 17 October 2003 the Istanbul Assize Court issued a detention order in respect of the applicant. According to the information in the case file, at the date of the detention order, the case of Mehmet Ali Günaydin is pending before the same court. Günaydın is one of the co-accused in another case brought against the applicant. However, the applicant and his wife are bringing separate proceedings in the cases before the Istanbul Assize Court.

B. The proceedings before the Investigation Officer

On 26 November 2003 the Istanbul Assize Court dismissed the applicant's requests for the termination of the proceedings and detention of his house.

On 25 December 2003 the Istanbul Assize Court detained the applicant.

On 12 January 2004 the applicant objected to the detention order and asked to be released. He also requested to be released under judicial supervision.

On 19 January 2004 the Investigation Officer refused the applicant's request.

On 22 January 2004 the applicant's lawyer appealed.

On 3 February 2004 the Prosecutor confirmed the decision of the Investigation Officer.

On 9 February 2004 the Istanbul Assize Court upheld the Prosecutor's opinion.

C. Criminal proceedings against the applicant

As regards the criminal proceedings brought against the applicant, on 23 October 2003 the Istanbul Assize Court detained the applicant.

Following several decisions by the trial court prolonging the detention period, on 30 June 2008 the Istanbul Assize Court ordered the applicant's release.

The applicant's pre-trial detention in respect of the cases before the Istanbul Assize Court has continued until the present day.

PROCEDURE

The case originated in an application (no. 45227/07) against the Federal Republic of Germany lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a German national, Mr Rainer Kellner (“the applicant”), on 25 January 2007.

The applicant was represented by Mr H. Schönborn, a lawyer practising in Erlangen. The German Government (“the Government”) were represented by their Agent, Mr K. Stoltenberg, Ministerialdirigent, Ministry of Justice.

The applicant alleged that his right to freedom of expression had been violated on account of a restraining order (Ausschlusshinweis) issued by a regional court preventing him from taking part in a public demonstration by a left-wing extremist organisation.

On 26 February 2008 the President of the Fifth Section decided to give notice of the application to the Government. Under the provisions of Article 29 § 3 of the Convention it was decided that, although the application was admissible, it was not necessary to pursue the case before the Court.

Written submissions (Rule 59 § 1) were received from European Union of Jewish Students, as third-party interveners, and from Mr Uwe Raschke (representative of NSU Watch).

The Court decides to take no further action in the present case in accordance with Article 31 of the Convention. It refers, in particular, to its decision of 3 April 2007 in the case of Pötschko v. Germany (no. 48235/06), where similar complaints under Article 10 of the Convention were considered and where it was also found that no further action was appropriate.

In the light of that decision, the Court requests the Registrar to remove the case from the list.
